post_text: It has come to our attention that some parents are confused about the school district’s communication plan in the event of a student or staff member testing positive for COVID-19. When we have confirmed a positive case, communication will go to all parents who have a student in that building. Additional communication will go to parents who have a student in the same classroom or ride the same bus. The parents of students who have been exposed to the positive case will receive a telephone call from the school district and/or the Warren County Health Department with instructions on how to quarantine. No other parents will receive these communications. If you hear of a case and you were not contacted, then you can assume the case was not in your child’s school or on your child’s bus. The school district may or may not issue a press release or post a statement on social media. We hope this clears up any confusion and puts parents' minds at ease. Have a good evening.

The Lebanon City Schools are announcing that at the close of business today, our student enrollment numbers for in-class instruction will be at capacity to accommodate safe spacing within our classrooms and other areas. As a result, beginning tomorrow, July 15, all new students registering for Lebanon City Schools will be automatically placed in the online program for the first semester. We understand that this placement will create a burden for working families. However, we cannot compromise the safety of our students and staff by overcrowding our classrooms and school buildings.

Students who are assigned to the online program are not required to perform their work during the traditional school day. They can perform the work once parents are at home, but that is a decision for the family to make. Let's all hope that by the start of the second semester, we can safely bring students back to school.

This is an important message from Lebanon City Schools. We were informed today that a student-athlete, who is a member of our girl's soccer team, has tested positive for the COVID-19 virus. It is not believed that the virus was contracted through the soccer program, but all protocols are being followed, including extra cleaning and disinfecting of the spaces and equipment used by the soccer program and a requirement that all athletes and coaches receive a negative COVID test prior to returning to practice. The student-athlete self-quarantined beginning in early July due to symptoms and has not returned to practice since. This is the protocol that we need everyone to follow. If you have any symptoms, stay home. We applaud this student and wish her a quick recovery.

This is an example of the type of communication parents can expect to receive if/when a Lebanon student or staff member tests positive for the virus. Contact tracing is being performed by the Warren County Health District and if your child was exposed, you will be contacted by them.

Lebanon City Schools has ONCE AGAIN been named a national Best Community for Music Education by the NAMM Foundation. This is the seventh year in a row Lebanon has earned this distinction and the eighth time overall. Only 47 schools in Ohio were selected this year and a total of 754 districts were given this award nationally. The award is given based on overall involvement in the music program, the health of music offerings in the schools, administrative support and other demographic data related to performing arts.

We're fortunate to have a group of dedicated music teachers focused on bringing top quality musical experiences to our students and community. Congratulations to each of them and THANK YOU for continuing this tradition and bringing the joy of making music to our community.

Potential penalties include:

Suspension of membership
Suspension of eligibility
Forfeiture of games
Forfeiture of championship rights
Probation
Reclamation of expenses for the conduct of investigations and all other fees/expenses associated therewith
Public Censure
Denial of participation in postseason tournaments (applicable to administrators, coaches and student-athletes)
Fines not to exceed $10,000 per occurrence
Other penalties as the executive director’s office deem appropriate
